awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Phase Stabilized Optical Frequency Comb for Precision Metrology, Quantum Sensing, Information Processing, and Novel Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the National Scientific Foundation Major Research Instrumentation program supports the acquisition of a phase stabilized optical frequency comb by the University of Nevada, Las Vegas (UNLV). The optical frequency comb (OFC) enables a broad range of research activities in the Departments of Physics, Chemistry, Electric engineering, and Geoscience. The instrument will expand research capabilities and ignite collaboration between 15 faculty at UNLV and roughly 50 of their associated students and postdocs. The equipment will be a cornerstone toward building a research center for exploring new methods and technologies in quantum sensing and information processing, connecting expertise in AMO physics, condensed matter physics, physical chemistry, electric engineering, and geoscience. This instrument will enable investigations of fundamental questions in science and engineering, advance the training of the diverse graduate and undergraduate STEM students at UNLV, and increase the skilled workforce available in the Southern Nevada area and the desert Southwest. The requested OFC will be the first advanced light source facility with extreme coherence and broad bandwidth in Nevada. Thus, installation of the requested instrument within a UNLV research core will enhance the capabilities of Southern Nevada economic development in quantum science, novel materials, and astrophysical and geological explorations. This project is jointly funded by the MPS (Mathematical and Physical Sciences) Directorate, the Physics (PHY) Division, the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), and the Office of Integrative Activities (OIA).

The OFC is the newest generation of light sources that combines accurate phase information (approximately 1 part per 10^20) in the frequency-domain and ultrafast temporal information (femtoseconds) in the time-domain simultaneously. It has been used as a precision optical frequency synthesizer to explore new phenomena in fundamental science and is a crucial component in the world's most precise atomic clock (Nobel Prize in Physics, 2005). Besides exhibiting an ultrabroad spectroscopic coverage and narrow linewidth, the OFC revolutionizes molecular spectroscopy with unprecedented speed and sensitivity, having already enabled successful applications in physics, chemistry, and environmental science. The OFC at UNLV will enable the following detailed studies: (1) development of a new generation of quantum sensors facilitating exploration of new physics beyond the Standard Model; (2) investigations of quantum computation platforms (photon, ion, superconducting circuit) and construction of a quantum network between them; (3) utilization and extension of novel asynchronous sampling pump-probe spectroscopy by dual-OFC in various studies in condensed matter physics and chemistry, such as probing driven topological phases in 2D systems and ultrafast photochemistry under high pressure; (4) study of novel synthesized materials, such as room-temperature superconductors (RTSC) by efficient nonlinear spectroscopy; (5) exploration of interstellar chemistry by performing broadband, high-resolution spectroscopy of cold molecules and probing ion-radical cold collisions; (6) study of radiochemistry by high resolution spectroscopy of molecules containing heavy elements; and (7) development of new technology for determining elemental abundances in solid rock samples.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We have successfully completed the acquisition, installation, and operation of a state-of-the-art optical frequency comb (OFC) system from TOPTICA in the Department of Physics and Astronomy at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas (UNLV).

The acquisition process was initiated immediately after the NSF MRI grant was approved in 2021. However, the manufacturing, delivery, and installation of the system faced significant delays due to disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic from 2021 to 2022. Despite these challenges, the system was fully delivered to UNLV in 2023. Over the next year, extensive installation, benchmark testing, and necessary manufacturer repairs were conducted to ensure the system's performance met stringent specifications. By the summer of 2024, the entire OFC system became fully operational, with all critical parameters verified through rigorous testing.

To celebrate the milestone of the OFC system becoming fully operational, a small-scale workshop was held in the summer of 2024 to launch initial scientific projects and address challenges related to sharing the system across multiple research efforts. Key infrastructure developments were subsequently implemented to meet growing demand and optimize utilization: (1) Advanced Experimental Control System: A process-oriented programming-based control system was developed to enable concurrent access by multiple users, ensuring efficient operation without deadlocks or delays. (2) Expanded Laboratory Space: A 600-square-foot lab was allocated by the Department of Physics and Astronomy to support an increasing number of interdisciplinary collaborations centered on the OFC system. (3) System Integration into a Rack Framework: The OFC system and its accessories were transitioned to a computer cluster rack, saving optical table space and improving overall stability and reliability. These advancements lay a solid foundation for future research and collaboration, ensuring the OFC system continues to serve as a cornerstone for cutting-edge scientific exploration at UNLV. By addressing operational challenges and preparing for increased usage, the department is well-positioned to support innovative research initiatives and expand its contributions to the broader scientific community.

Supported by the OFC system, three primary research projects proposed in the NSF grant have been successfully initiated: (1) exploring new physics beyond the Standard Model by precision measurements of polar molecular ions, (2) development and application of asynchronous sampling pump-probe spectroscopy to study condensed matter physics and chemistry, providing new insights into ultrafast molecular dynamics and material properties,  and (3) exploration of interstellar chemistry by performing broadband, high-resolution spectroscopy of cold molecules. Other proposed research activities, outlined in the grant, are expected to commence in 2025 as the OFC system continues to expand its operational capabilities.

In parallel, the launch of the OFC system has catalyzed external collaborations, significantly broadening UNLV’s research impact across multiple disciplines. Notable examples include participation in the HDRFS (Harnessing the Data Revolution for Fire Science) program, led by the Nevada System of Higher Education (NSHE), which leverages advanced spectroscopy for environmental monitoring, and a collaborative project with Professor Liu at the University of Louisville, supported by NASA, to apply OFC technologies in astrophysics research.

The introduction of the OFC system has significantly expanded research horizons at UNLV, fostering interdisciplinary investigations and positioning the university as a hub for innovation in quantum science, precision measurement, and spectroscopy. These advancements are driving cutting-edge scientific discoveries while simultaneously creating transformative opportunities in education. The OFC system is being actively integrated into academic programs, such as PHYS 493 (Independent Research) and PHYS 413 (Intermediate Laboratory), to provide students with hands-on experience using state-of-the-art technology. Workshops, seminars, and collaborative research initiatives are equipping both undergraduate and graduate students with the skills needed to thrive in high-tech industries and research fields.

By combining research excellence with education, the OFC system is strengthening UNLV’s role in training the next generation of scientists and engineers, particularly those from underrepresented backgrounds. These efforts are creating a robust talent pipeline and ensuring that innovations in quantum science and optical technology benefit a diverse and inclusive community. This dual focus on research and education is building a strong foundation for long-term growth in collaborative and transformative efforts across physics, chemistry, and related fields, cementing UNLV’s position as a leader in cutting-edge science and workforce development.
